bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 23, 1900

div1.p: Reed describes a dinner given for Finlay and the general acceptance of the mosquito theory. He will continue tests involving infected clothing.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 23, 1900
div1.opener:
A Kiss
for Doogs.
Columbia Barracks,
Decr 23rd 1900,
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
This is
Sunday evening, just after
dinner, and I really ate so
heartily that I feel rather
“logy” for letter writing-
Not that we had an extra
good dinner, for aside
from a passable soup
and a chicken pot-pie,
there was nothing else
to tempt one- How I
long once more for a
taste of good beef-steak
and for a hot roll! as
for a few oysters, I would
give half of my salary!
Yesterday I received your
darling abbreviated letter
of Tuesday last -- and was
so delighted to hear that
you are “feeling very well”
once more and able to
get about- What a seige
my sweet wifie has had!
The calendar came, too,
yesterday- It made me
laugh & has afforded
much amusement to all
of us -- who wrote the
verse that adorns it?
Did you concoct that?
or was it Dr Nash?
By the way, last evening,
I attended quite a swell
banquet in Havana, given
to Dr Finlay by some
seventy or eighty physicians
of Havana- It was a very
recherche' affair and extreme-
ly enjoyable- Everything was
in Spanish- The Governor
General was there- The toasts
were all in Spanish and
the speeches, while flattering
to Dr Finlay, for his concep-
tion of the theory, gave us
full credit for the discov-
ery- It is to me surprising
and extremely satisfactory
to see how very quickly
the profession of Havana
have accepted our re-
sults- I have seen in
the Washington Post, Gen.
Sternberg's statement about
the cablegram from me-
I suppose that the Post
will now have another
silly editorial on the subject.
I have allowed the men
who have spent 20 nights
in our infected clothing house
to come out, and they are now
in quarantine- Two other
soldiers are now occupy-
ing the house & sleeping
not only in the very same beds
& between the very same sheets
on which our yellow fever
patients have slep rested
during their attacks, but
they sleep in the very shirts
that our patients wore
during throughout their entire sickness!
If anything should give them
the disease, this should suc-
ceed! Don't you think so?
Infected clothing and bedding
has been a horrible night-
mare during these past
300 years, but me thinks
it will die out very early
in the next century! yellow
fever can no more be
transmitted in that way
than can Intermittent Fever!
How Gen. Sternberg & hosts
of others could have be-
lieved in the contagious-
ness of clothing and of the
stools of yellow fever pa-
tients I cannot possibly
see- They were simply ac-
cepting the statements of
others who had nothing
on which to base such
statements. A little careful
testing of this theory has
served to knock it com-
pletely into smithereens!
I thank God that I did
not accept anybody's opin-
ion on this subject, but
determined to put it to
a thorough test with hu-
man beings in order to
see what would happen.
my own observations at
Pinar del Rio convinced
me that infected bedding
was indeed a myth-
Actual trial has proven
that I was right -- and that
what the medical profession
believed was wrong!
So you have dared send
to your dear old Mr
Mantee one of mother Greer's
fruit-cakes? Do you want
me to have gout, too? Look
here, lovie, dear, how did
you send it? by express?
I must send to town and
make inquiry about it-
How sweet in dearest
Miss Invalid to think of
her Mr Mosquito! When
it arrives, I shall pro-
ceed to put my “probos-
cis” into it and sip its
juices! I know that Dar-
boy will thoroughly en-
joy his cake- I got, also,
our dear little daughter's
picture, which papa con-
siders to be excellent- What
a precious love she is!
I shall be so glad when Christ-
mas has come and gone and
New Year has come, for then
only a few weeks will elapse
before I can turn my face
homeward toward my precious
girls, whom I want to see
more than words can tell.
Monday morning -- 24th, well, I suppose
that darling little daughter goes to
Annapolis, to-day, to spend Christmas
week- Papa hopes that she will
have a most delightful trip.
She must write and tell him all
about it- Papa hopes, too, that
dear mother won't have an utterly
stupid time, being left all alone-
Don't forget to get you a pretty
present, sweetheart- write and
tell me about it in your
next. Papa is so sorry that he
has to wish his darling oomsey
a Merry Christmas at such a long
distance- Bless my precious girls'
hearts- Love & kisses & kisses & love-
